title: Auto and Home Insurance Deep Dive

sections.title: Fortify the Things You Drive and Own
sections.subtitle: Audit your auto and property policies, plug coverage gaps, and negotiate smarter premiums

sections.title: What You'll Do
items: Decode every section of your auto and homeowners (or renters) declarations page
Benchmark liability, collision, and comprehensive limits against real-world replacement costs
Identify discounts and bundling strategies that reduce premiums without sacrificing coverage
Build a renewal checklist you can reuse every policy anniversary

sections.title: Why Property Coverage Needs Annual Maintenance
sections.content: Vehicles depreciate, home repair costs rise, and life circumstances change. The coverage you bought three years ago may no longer reflect replacement values or your current risk profile. Treat insurance as a living system: review deductibles, endorsements, and liability limits whenever you add drivers, finish a renovation, or purchase valuable gear.

points.title: Liability Coverage
points.description: Pays for injuries and property damage you cause. State minimums are rarely enough—target 100/300/100 or higher if you have assets.

points.title: Collision vs. Comprehensive
points.description: Collision covers your car when you hit something; comprehensive covers theft, weather, and vandalism. Evaluate the car's value to decide deductibles.

points.title: Uninsured/Underinsured Motorist
points.description: Protects you if the other driver has insufficient coverage. Match limits to your liability coverage whenever possible.

sections.title: Deductible Rule of Thumb
sections.content: Choose the highest deductible you could comfortably pay out-of-pocket tomorrow. Higher deductibles lower premiums, but only if you can self-insure the difference.

sections.title: Homeowners & Renters Coverage Layers
sections.content: Property policies are more than dwelling coverage. Personal property, loss of use, medical payments, and personal liability add up to a comprehensive shield. Inventory belongings with photos or spreadsheets, note expensive items that need scheduled endorsements (jewelry, instruments, collectibles), and verify that coverage limits reflect today’s replacement costs.

sections.title: Bundling and Discounts
sections.content: Insurers reward safe behavior and consolidated business. Common discounts include multi-policy bundles, telematics driving programs, automatic payments, loyalty credits, security systems, and good student rates. Capture the savings but evaluate whether bundling sacrifices coverage quality—compare standalone quotes to keep leverage.

sections.title: Policy Optimization Sprint
steps: Download the declarations pages for your auto and home/renters policies
List current liability limits, deductibles, and premium amounts for each coverage
Research recommended limits for your state and asset level (use the provided worksheet or links)
Call or email your agent to request quotes for increased liability/umbrella coverage and higher deductibles
Document available discounts, note gaps, and schedule a 12-month renewal review reminder

sections.title: When to Add Umbrella Coverage
sections.content: Once your net worth exceeds your auto liability limits, a personal umbrella policy becomes invaluable. For $150–$300 per year, you can add $1–$2 million in additional liability protection that applies after your auto or home policy limits are exhausted.

sections.title: Use Comparison APIs
sections.content: Web services like The Zebra, Policygenius, or independent agency portals let you pull multiple quotes without a dozen phone calls. Export results to your workbook and track renewal conversations year over year.
